questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of galactorrhoea. She also complains of a 5-year history of dyspepsia and persistent use of PPIs. Examination reveals a BMI of 23.5 kg/m2, and galactorrhoea was noticed. Slight neck enlargement was noticed during examination. Investigations show:
prolactin: 980 mU/l (50-500 mU/l)
estradiol: 85 pmol/l (130-500)
LH of 3.1 mU/l (3.5-8)
FSH of 2.8 mU/l (3-8)
Serum calcium: 11.2 mg/dl (8.5-10.5)
Ultrasonography revealed a parathyroid enlargement and a 99mTcO4/MIBI scan showed
two hyperplastic lesions.
What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The triad of prolactinoma, hyperparathyroidism, and probable gastrinoma (due to chronic dyspepsia and PPI use) is diagnostic of MEN type 1.
Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) is a hereditary disorder caused by mutations in the MEN1 gene (menin protein), with autosomal dominant inheritance.

  • The classical triad includes:
    • Pituitary tumors (e.g., prolactinoma, acromegaly)
    • Parathyroid hyperplasia/adenomas (→ hypercalcemia)
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (e.g., gastrinoma, insulinoma)
  • In this patient:
    • Galactorrhoea + raised prolactin + low gonadotropins → Prolactinoma
    • Hypercalcemia + parathyroid hyperplasia → Hyperparathyroidism
    • Dyspepsia requiring PPI for 5 years → suggests Zollinger-Ellison syndrome from gastrinoma

Explanation of other options:

Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome (Option A): Typically includes Addison's disease, hypoparathyroidism, and mucocutaneous candidiasis-not seen here.

Acromegaly (Option B): Would present with GH excess, not isolated prolactin elevation or parathyroid and gastrin-related features.

MEN 2A (Option C): Includes medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid hyperplasia, but pituitary tumors and gastrinomas are not features.

Key Takeaway:
MEN type 1 presents with pituitary, parathyroid, and pancreatic (gastrinoma) tumors-the findings in this case strongly support that diagnosis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman is complaining of fatigue and weight loss. She was successfully treated medically for a prolactinoma 3 years ago, and it is suspected that she might now have MEN-1. Which of the following underlying conditions is she most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has a history of prolactinoma, which is a pituitary tumor-one of the key components of MEN-1. Among the three classic manifestations of MEN-1 (pituitary, parathyroid, pancreatic), parathyroid hyperplasia is:

  • The most common and earliest manifestation of MEN-1
  • Leads to primary hyperparathyroidism and resultant hypercalcemia
  • May present with fatigue, depression, weight loss, or nephrolithiasis

Although pancreatic islet tumors (e.g., gastrinomas, insulinomas) and pituitary tumors are also seen, parathyroid hyperplasia is present in >90% of MEN-1 patients and is usually the first manifestation.

  • MEN-1 is due to a mutation in the MEN1 gene (menin)
  • Inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern
  • Medullary carcinoma of thyroid is seen in MEN-2, not MEN-1

Explanation of other options:

Medullary carcinoma of thyroid (Option A): Seen in MEN-2, not MEN-1.

Pancreatic islet-cell tumour (Option C): Common in MEN-1, but less frequent than parathyroid involvement.

Pituitary adenoma (Option D): Already present in this patient; question asks about the most likely associated new condition.

Key Takeaway:
Parathyroid hyperplasia is the most frequent and earliest endocrine abnormality in MEN-1, often causing asymptomatic hypercalcemia.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to casualty with a sudden loss of vision in his right eye. His only history of note is a previous cerebellar haemorrhage. On examination, he has Blood pressure of 130/86 mmHg, evidence of bilateral retinal angiomas, and a partial retinal detachment in his right eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has classic features of Von Hippel–Lindau (VHL) syndrome, a rare autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the VHL tumor suppressor gene:

  • Retinal hemangioblastomas (angiomas) → may cause exudative retinal detachment or vision loss
  • CNS hemangioblastomas, especially in the cerebellum → prior cerebellar hemorrhage supports this
  • Renal cell carcinoma (especially clear cell type)
  • Pheochromocytomas (seen in ~20% of families, often bilateral)
  • Pancreatic cysts or neuroendocrine tumors

The mean age of presentation is in the 2nd to 3rd decade, consistent with this case.

  • VHL is classified as a phakomatosis (neurocutaneous syndrome)
  • Early diagnosis is critical to prevent vision loss and manage tumors

Explanation of other options:

Simple traumatic retinal detachment (Option A): No trauma history; bilateral angiomas point to an inherited cause.

Clotting disorder (Option B): Could explain hemorrhage, but not retinal angiomas or this specific tumor profile.

Bleeding due to hypertension (Option C): BP is normal; hypertensive retinopathy is unlikely at this age with this BP.

Key Takeaway:

VHL syndrome should be suspected in young patients with retinal angiomas, CNS hemorrhage, and retinal detachment.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of MEN-1?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is characteristic of MEN 2, not MEN 1.

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN-1) is also called Werner's syndrome and is caused by mutations in the MEN1 gene encoding menin. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

Classic triad of MEN 1 involves the 3 Ps:

  1. Parathyroid hyperplasia/adenoma → hypercalcemia (most common feature, ~90%) (Option D)
  2. Pituitary tumors → mostly prolactinomas, but also GH-secreting or non-functioning adenomas (Option A)
  3. Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors → gastrinomas, insulinomas, glucagonomas, VIPomas (Option C)
  • Glucagonomas cause hyperglycemia, weight loss, and necrolytic migratory erythema
  • MEN 2, not MEN 1, is associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and marfanoid features

Key Takeaway:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a hallmark of MEN 2, not MEN 1, which primarily involves parathyroid, pituitary, and pancreatic tumors.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after brisk running. Her blood pressure is noted to be 185/110 mmHg on admission. She admits to episodic headaches and feeling stressed and anxious. She is of normal appearance. Her serum calcium on admission is noted to be 12 mg/dl with normal renal function. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a possible adrenal mass.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of pheochromocytoma (adrenal mass + paroxysmal HTN) and hypercalcemia suggests MEN-2A, which involves both parathyroid hyperplasia and pheochromocytoma.
Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2A (MEN-2A) is an autosomal dominant syndrome caused by RET proto-oncogene mutation on chromosome 10.

MEN-2A triad:

  1. Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) - 100% penetrance
  2. Pheochromocytoma - ~50%
  3. Parathyroid hyperplasia - ~20-30%

In this patient:

  • Adrenal mass + episodic headache + paroxysmal HTN → Pheochromocytoma
  • Hypercalcemia → likely parathyroid hyperplasia
  • These two together strongly suggest MEN-2A

Workup should include:

  • Plasma metanephrines
  • Serum calcitonin and neck ultrasound for medullary carcinoma
  • RET gene testing

Explanation of other options:

Pheochromocytoma (Option A): Seen here, but does not explain hypercalcemia.

MEN-1 (Option B): Involves parathyroid, pituitary, and pancreatic tumors, not pheochromocytoma or MTC.

MEN-2B (Option D): Involves pheochromocytoma and MTC, but also has marfanoid habitus and mucosal neuromas, which are absent here.

Key Takeaway:
 MEN-2A involves pheochromocytoma, parathyroid hyperplasia, and medullary thyroid carcinoma, and is suggested by hypercalcemia + adrenal mass + hypertension.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman with Hashimoto's thyroiditis presents to the clinic for review. She is managed with thyroxine 125 mcg/day replacement. She presents to the clinic complaining of bilateral loin pain.
Investigations;
Hb 12.1 g/dl
WCC 5.4 x 10^9/L
PLT 294 x 10^9/L
Na+ 139 mmol/l
K+ 3.3 mmol/l
Creatinine 1.40 mg/dl
HCO3- 15 mmol/l
KUB Evidence of nephrocalcinosis
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Distal (Type 1) RTA is associated with hypokalemia, metabolic acidosis, nephrocalcinosis, and autoimmune disorders like Hashimoto’s thyroiditis.
Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) refers to normal anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis due to defective renal acid handling.

RTA Type 1 (Distal RTA):

  • Defect in H+secretion in distal nephron
  • Hypokalemia, low bicarbonate, normal anion gap metabolic acidosis
  • Hypercalciuria and alkaline urine → nephrocalcinosis, renal stones
  • Associated with autoimmune diseases: Sjögren's syndrome, Hashimoto's thyroiditis, SLE

This patient presents with:

  • Autoimmune hypothyroidism (Hashimoto's)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Low bicarbonate
  • Nephrocalcinosis
    → Classic for Type 1 RTA

Explanation of other options:

RTA Type 4 (Option A): Causes hyperkalemia, not seen here.

Medullary sponge kidney (Option B): May cause nephrocalcinosis, but not associated with acidosis or hypokalemia.

RTA Type 2 (Option C): Proximal RTA with bicarbonate wasting, but not typically associated with nephrocalcinosis or autoimmune thyroiditis.

Key Takeaway:
 Distal RTA (Type 1) is the only form of RTA associated with nephrocalcinosis, hypokalemia, metabolic acidosis, and autoimmune diseases like Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man is admitted to hospital in a comatose condition. His wife gives a history of past episodes of sweating and palpitations, confusion, and occasional abnormal behaviour that improves with intake of glucose.. On examination, his pulse is 92 bpm and his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. His plasma catecholamine level is normal, and blood glucose is 65 mg/dl. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Symptoms relieved by glucose in the setting of low blood sugar strongly indicate hypoglycemia due to insulinoma, especially when Whipple's triad is met.
This patient's symptoms suggest recurrent hypoglycemia with both autonomic and neuroglycopenic features:

  • Whipple's triad:
    • Hypoglycemic symptoms (sweating, confusion, behavior change)
    • Low plasma glucose (<70 mg/dL)
    • Symptom relief with glucose intake
  • Insulinoma is the most common islet-cell tumor causing endogenous hyperinsulinemia
  • Often benign, but may be associated with MEN1
  • Plasma catecholamines are normal, ruling out pheochromocytoma

Explanation of other options:

MEN-II syndrome (Option A): Associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid hyperplasia, not hypoglycemia.

Phaeochromocytoma (Option B): Typically presents with episodic hypertension, palpitations, headache not hypoglycemia.

Pseudodementia (Option D): Mimics dementia but is due to major depression, not relieved by glucose and not associated with autonomic symptoms.

Key Takeaway:
 Insulinoma should be suspected in any patient with recurrent neuroglycopenic and autonomic symptoms relieved by glucose Whipple's triad is key to diagnosis.

choices.text: Mutation of a muscle voltage-gated sodium channel
Mutation in a muscle voltage-gated potassium channel
Mutation in a renal potassium channel
Mutation in a muscle voltage-gated calcium channel

questions.text: A 20-year-old student is brought to emergency after he had been playing that afternoon, and while resting (after having had a pasta meal), complained of generalised weakness. He was unable to stand and had to be carried in by his friends. His potassium level was noted to be 2.1 mmol/l. Urine screen for diabetic and laxative abuse was normal. He has had similar attacks since his early teenage years. Symptoms were aborted by potassium chloride. What type of mutation best fits the underlying pathology of this autosomal-dominant condition involving intermittent paralysis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is classically caused by mutations in the CACNA1S gene encoding the skeletal muscle voltage-gated calcium channel.

  • The patient exhibits episodic flaccid weakness triggered by high carbohydrate intake or rest after exertion, with documented hypokalemia
  • This points to Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis, an autosomal dominant channelopathy
  • Most commonly due to mutations in the CACNA1S gene → affecting voltage-gated calcium channels in skeletal muscle
  • Symptoms:
    • Recurrent attacks of flaccid paralysis lasting hours
    • Often starts in adolescence
    • Triggers include high-carb meals, rest after exercise, stress
  • Potassium supplementation provides rapid symptomatic relief

Explanation of other options:

Muscle sodium channel mutation (Option A): Seen in Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis, not the hypokalemic form

Muscle potassium channel mutation (Option B): Associated with Andersen-Tawil syndrome, features dysmorphism and arrhythmias-not classic for this case

Renal potassium channel mutation (Option C): Does not explain episodic paralysis-seen in disorders like Bartter syndrome

Key Takeaway:
 Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is commonly caused by a mutation in the CACNA1S gene encoding skeletal muscle voltage-gated calcium channels.

choices.text: Somatostatin, ACTH and calcitonin may all be raised
Contrast spiral-CT scanning is effective in demonstrating the primary tumour in 90% of cases
Curative surgery is possible in the majority of casess
There is almost always an association with MEN-1

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to the diabetes clinic for review. She has suffered from diabetes mellitus for many years and has now progressed from sulphonylurea treatment to insulin therapy. A history of gallstones is noted, and she failed to tolerate metformin due to chronic diarrhoea. She has been slowly losing weight over the past few months and has mild anaemia. Ultrasound scan of her liver reveals a suggestion of several small metastases within the liver. When considering that this woman has a primary pancreatic tumour, which of the following statements best fits the condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient likely has a somatostatinoma, a rare pancreatic endocrine tumor with characteristic features such as diabetes, gallstones, diarrhea, weight loss, and anemia.

  • Somatostatinomas are extremely rare tumors with an incidence of ~1 per 40 million per year
  • Typical features include:
    • Diabetes or impaired glucose tolerance (seen in up to 95%)
    • Gallstones (due to inhibition of cholecystokinin)
    • Weight loss (25%) and anemia (14%)
    • Chronic diarrhea due to inhibition of multiple gastrointestinal hormones
  • These tumors can be multi-secretory, with elevated levels of somatostatin, ACTH, and calcitonin
  • Liver metastases are common at presentation, reducing chances of curative surgery
  • MEN-1 association is rare (~7%), unlike insulinomas or gastrinomas (Option D ruled out)
  • Contrast spiral-CT detects the primary tumor in ~50% of cases-not 90%(Option B ruled out)
  • DOTATATE PET or endoscopic ultrasound may be more sensitive
  • Treatment may involve hepatic embolization for palliation
  • Curative surgery rare due to early metastasis at presentation (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaway:
 Somatostatinomas often present with diabetes, gallstones, and diarrhea, and may secrete somatostatin, ACTH, and calcitonin.

questions.text: A 33-year-old banker presents to the clinic. Apart from a history of reflux symptoms, her previous medical history is unremarkable. She gives a history of increasing fatigue, being sometimes unable to leave her bedroom. She feels unable to concentrate, has headaches, intermittent sore throats and feels that when she can sleep, she awakens unrefreshed. Full blood count, viscosity, urea and electrolytes, liver function testing, thyroid function testing and a Synacthen test have all been normal. On examination in the clinic, there are no abnormal physical findings in this normal-weight, normal-height young woman. What diagnosis fits best with this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A young adult with profound fatigue, unrefreshing sleep, and normal physical and lab findings strongly suggests chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS).

  • CFS typically affects young to middle-aged adults, with a female preponderance
  • Often follows a flu-like illness; a viral trigger (e.g., EBV) is suspected, though not proven
  • Patients report:
    • Severe fatigue not relieved by rest
    • Cognitive dysfunction, often described as'brain fog'
    • Sleep disturbances, where sleep is unrefreshing
    • Myalgia, sore throat, and headaches
  • All routine investigations are typically normal, including:
    • Thyroid function
    • Synacthen test (rules out Addison's)
    • Blood counts, liver, and renal parameters
  • Diagnosis is clinical and one of exclusion
  • Management includes:
    • Patient education, cognitive behavioral therapy
    • Graded exercise therapy
    • Low-dose tricyclics (e.g., amitriptyline) may be useful for sleep and pain

Explanation of other options:

Addison's disease (Option A): Ruled out by normal Synacthen test

Hypothyroidism (Option B): Ruled out by normal thyroid profile

Myasthenia gravis (Option D): Would present with fluctuating muscle weakness (e.g., ptosis, diplopia)-not generalized fatigue alone

Key Takeaway:

Chronic fatigue syndrome presents with debilitating fatigue and unrefreshing sleep in the absence of any objective abnormalities on examination or routine tests.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl referred for evaluation of menstrual disturbances. She weighs only 38 kg and is 1.78 m tall. She is emaciated, her skin is dry, and she has excessive growth of lanugo hair. She has been amenorrhoeic for 9 months. Her cortisol level is elevated, her Free T4 is normal. She has anaemia and associated reduced white cell and platelet count. Which of the following diagnoses is most likely to fit with this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with classic signs of anorexia nervosa, a psychiatric disorder with profound medical consequences:

  • Severe underweight (BMI < 17.5)
  • Amenorrhea >3 months
  • Lanugo hair (fine, soft body hair seen with nutritional deficiency)
  • Dry skin, bradycardia, hypotension (autonomic and hormonal dysfunction)
  • Pancytopenia due to bone marrow suppression
  • Cortisol elevated, but TSH and Free T4 remain normal (non-thyroidal illness pattern)

Anorexia nervosa involves:

  • Low levels of FSH, LH, and estrogen
  • Metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalcemia

Explanation of other options:

Addison's disease (Option A): Causes weight loss and hyperpigmentation but not amenorrhea, lanugo, or normal thyroid function

HIV (Option B): May cause weight loss and cytopenias, but not classic for lanugo, amenorrhea, or hormonal profile

Hypothyroidism (Option C): Causes dry skin and amenorrhea, but would show low Free T4, not elevated cortisol, and not lanugo or extreme weight loss

Key Takeaway:

Anorexia nervosa should be suspected in young females with extreme weight loss, amenorrhea, lanugo hair, and hematologic abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause for secondary hypertriglyceridemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic alcohol use is a well-known cause of secondary hypertriglyceridemia, mainly due to increased hepatic VLDL production.

Hypertriglyceridemia may be primary (genetic) or secondary (acquired). Secondary causes include:

  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Alcoholism
  • Hypothyroidism (mainly hypercholesterolemia)
  • Nephrotic syndrome (mainly hypercholesterolemia)
  • Drugs: thiazides, corticosteroids, estrogens, cyclosporine, protease inhibitors

In alcoholism, the metabolism of ethanol increases hepatic NADH, promoting fatty acid synthesis and triglyceride production. This leads to VLDL overproduction and elevated plasma triglycerides.

Explanation of other options:

Addison disease (Option A): Causes hypoglycemia and weight loss, not associated with hypertriglyceridemia.

SLE (Option C): Can cause secondary dyslipidemia due to steroid therapy, but not a direct cause of isolated hypertriglyceridemia.

Thyrotoxicosis (Option D): Tends to lower LDL and triglycerides; hypothyroidism, not hyperthyroidism, is linked to lipid disorders.

Key Takeaway:

Alcoholism is a major secondary cause of hypertriglyceridemia, through hepatic overproduction of VLDL.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man has Lipoprotein lipase deficiency.
Which one of the following features is most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

LPL deficiency leads to accumulation of triglyceride-rich chylomicrons, causing severe hypertriglyceridemia.

Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is the key enzyme responsible for hydrolyzing triglycerides in chylomicrons and VLDL particles into free fatty acids.

  • In LPL deficiency (also called familial chylomicronemia syndrome):
    • Chylomicrons cannot be cleared from plasma
    • Leads to marked hypertriglyceridemia, often >1000 mg/dL
    • Risk of acute pancreatitis, eruptive xanthomas, lipemia retinalis
  • Inheritance is autosomal recessive
  • Similar phenotype also seen in:
    • ApoC-II deficiency
    • ApoA5 deficiency
    • GPIHBP1 or lipase maturation factor 1 mutations

Explanation of other options:

Marked hypercholesterolemia (Option A): Seen in familial hypercholesterolemia, not in LPL deficiency.

Reduced chylomicrons (Option B): LPL deficiency causes elevated chylomicrons, not reduced.

Familial Hypercholesterolemia (Option D): Different disorder involving LDL receptor pathway, not triglyceride clearance.

Key Takeaway:

LPL deficiency causes massive hypertriglyceridemia due to failure to clear chylomicrons, often presenting with pancreatitis and eruptive xanthomas.

questions.text: Which one of the following protein defects is most likely to be associated with very high levels of plasma chylomicrons?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Apoprotein CII is a critical activator of lipoprotein lipase, and its deficiency leads to accumulation of chylomicrons in plasma.

Chylomicrons are large triglyceride-rich lipoproteins synthesized in intestinal epithelial cells to transport dietary fats.

  • Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is required to hydrolyze triglycerides in chylomicrons
  • Apoprotein CII acts as a cofactor for LPL activation
  • In its absence, LPL is inactive, leading to:
    • Accumulation of chylomicrons in plasma
    • Severe hypertriglyceridemia
    • Risk of pancreatitis, eruptive xanthomas, lipemia retinalis
  • This resembles the phenotype seen in familial LPL deficiency, but occurs slightly later in life
  • Management: Strict low-fat diet with medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) that bypass chylomicron transport

Explanation of other options:

Apoprotein E (Option A): Involved in remnant uptake; mutations lead to Type III dysbetalipoproteinemia, not chylomicronemia

Apoprotein AII (Option C): Component of HDL, not involved in chylomicron metabolism

Lipoprotein B (Option D): Refers to ApoB100 (VLDL, LDL) and ApoB48 (chylomicrons); mutations affect synthesis but not LPL activation

Key Takeaway:

Apoprotein CII deficiency results in failure to activate lipoprotein lipase, causing severe chylomicronemia and hypertriglyceridemia.

questions.text: You review a 67-year-old man for dyslipidemia. He is taking atorvastatin 40 mg/day. Which of the following drugs should be used with caution?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Erythromycin is a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor that increases statin plasma levels, raising the risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis.
 Statins, including atorvastatin, are metabolized by the cytochrome P450 3A4 enzyme system.

  • CYP3A4 inhibitors (e.g., erythromycin, azole antifungals, HIV protease inhibitors) reduce statin clearance → ↑ statin concentration → ↑ risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis
  • Caution is essential when combining these drugs with moderate to high-dose statins (e.g., atorvastatin 40-80 mg/day)

Explanation of other options:

Warfarin (Option A): Statins may potentiate warfarin's effect, requiring INR monitoring, but do not increase myopathy risk.

Digoxin (Option C): Statins can slightly increase digoxin levels via P-glycoprotein inhibition, but myopathy risk is not significantly increased.

Antacids (Option D): Do not significantly interact with statins and are considered safe.

Key Takeaway:

Erythromycin significantly increases the risk of statin-induced myopathy due to CYP3A4 inhibition and should be used cautiously with atorvastatin.

choices.text: Failure of the LDL receptors to move to the cell surface

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man is referred after his first myocardial infarction for your opinion. He has a total cholesterol level of 370 mg/dl, with normal triglycerides. You note the presence of corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas.
Which of the following genetic factors is not likely to be a cause of hypercholesterolemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Increased LDL receptors would enhance clearance of LDL, and thus reduce serum cholesterol-not cause hypercholesterolemia.
 This patient likely has familial hypercholesterolemia (FH), an autosomal dominant disorder caused by defective LDL receptor pathway.

  • Pathophysiology:
    • LDLR mutations → ↓ LDL uptake by hepatocytes
    • APOB mutations → defective binding of LDL to receptor
    • PCSK9 gain-of-function mutations → increased degradation of LDL receptors
    • LDLRAP1 mutations (autosomal recessive FH) → impaired receptor internalization
  • Clinical features:
    • Very high LDL levels
    • Normal triglycerides
    • Tendon xanthomas, corneal arcus, early MI
    • Heterozygotes: CHD in 30s-40s
    • Homozygotes: Severe CHD in childhood

Explanation of other options:

Increased PCSK9 degradation (Option B): Gain-of-function mutations lead to accelerated LDL receptor breakdown, causing hypercholesterolemia.

Failure of LDL receptors to move to the cell surface (Option C): A known mutation class in FH impairs receptor transport.

Abnormal receptor-binding to LDL (Option D): Occurs in APOB-related FH, where LDL cannot bind the receptor properly.

Key Takeaway:

Excess LDL receptors enhance LDL clearance and do not cause hypercholesterolemia unlike mutations that reduce receptor number/function or increase their degradation.

questions.text: Which of the following secondary causes of hyperlipidemia result in predominantly hypercholesterolemia, as opposed to hypertriglyceridemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nephrotic syndrome is a classical secondary cause of predominant hypercholesterolemia due to hepatic overproduction of lipoproteins in response to hypoalbuminemia.
 Secondary hyperlipidemias may present with either predominantly raised cholesterol or raised triglycerides, depending on the underlying condition:

  • Hypercholesterolemia-dominant causes:
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Cholestatic liver disease
      These conditions upregulate hepatic production of apolipoprotein B-containing lipoproteins (e.g., LDL).
  • In nephrotic syndrome, hypoalbuminemia stimulates:
    • Hepatic lipoprotein synthesis
    • Reduced clearance of LDL
      → Resulting in elevated LDL and total cholesterol

Explanation of other options:

Diabetes mellitus (Option A): Typically causes hypertriglyceridemia, especially in insulin resistance, due to increased VLDL and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity.

Bendrofluazide (Option B): A thiazide diuretic that causes mild hypertriglyceridemia and occasionally raises LDL levels.

Alcohol (Option D): Elevates triglycerides, especially via hepatic overproduction of VLDL and impaired clearance.

Key Takeaway:

Nephrotic syndrome is a secondary cause of hypercholesterolemia, while conditions like diabetes and alcohol use cause hypertriglyceridemia.
